ICD10_Description: Migraine without aura, not intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: ≥5 attacks; 4-72 hours duration; ≥2 of: unilateral/pulsating/moderate-severe/aggravated by activity; ≥1 of: nausea-vomiting/photo-phonophobia
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Episodic codes NOT covered for Botox under Medicare LCDs. Use for CGRP mAbs if <15 headache days/month.
Common_Denial_Risks: Using for Botox claims = automatic denial

ICD10_Description: Migraine without aura, not intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: ≥5 attacks; 4-72 hours duration; ≥2 of: unilateral/pulsating/moderate-severe/aggravated by activity; ≥1 of: nausea-vomiting/photo-phonophobia
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Most common episodic migraine code. Valid for CGRP mAbs, gepants, triptans.
Common_Denial_Risks: Using for Botox = denial; misuse on chronic patients loses appeal leverage

ICD10_Description: Migraine without aura, intractable, with status migrainosus
ICHD3_Description: Migraine without aura with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Migraine attack >72 hours despite treatment; debilitating headache continuous for >72 hours
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Intractable indicates treatment-resistant. May support escalation to CGRP therapies.

ICD10_Description: Migraine without aura, intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: ≥5 attacks meeting criteria; failed multiple acute treatments
Medications_Applicable: Gepants, Ditans, CGRP mAbs for prevention
LCD_Coverage_Notes: 'Intractable' supports step therapy bypass arguments for refractory patients.

ICD10_Description: Migraine with aura, not intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: ≥2 attacks with aura; visual/sensory/speech symptoms 5-60 min; ≥1 aura symptom unilateral; headache within 60 min of aura
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Episodic code. NOT valid for Botox under Medicare LCDs.

ICD10_Description: Migraine with aura, not intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: ≥2 attacks with aura; visual/sensory/speech symptoms 5-60 min; ≥1 aura symptom unilateral; headache within 60 min of aura
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Standard episodic migraine with aura code.

ICD10_Description: Migraine with aura, intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Aura-associated migraine >72 hours despite treatment
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Supports urgent/emergent treatment escalation.

ICD10_Description: Migraine with aura, intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: ≥2 attacks with aura; failed multiple treatments
LCD_Coverage_Notes: 'Intractable' designation supports refractory status arguments.

ICD10_Description: Hemiplegic migraine, not intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Migraine with aura including motor weakness; fully reversible motor and visual/sensory/speech symptoms
LCD_Coverage_Notes: CRITICAL: Triptans CONTRAINDICATED in hemiplegic migraine. Direct pathway to gepants/ditans.

ICD10_Description: Hemiplegic migraine, not intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Migraine with aura including motor weakness; fully reversible motor and visual/sensory/speech symptoms
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Hemiplegic subtype = automatic triptan step therapy bypass per AHS guidelines.
Common_Denial_Risks: Document motor weakness clearly in notes

ICD10_Description: Hemiplegic migraine, intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Hemiplegic migraine >72 hours or failing treatment
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Refractory hemiplegic migraine requires specialized management.
Common_Denial_Risks: Urgent neurology referral may be needed

ICD10_Description: Hemiplegic migraine, intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Hemiplegic migraine failing multiple treatments
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Supports direct CGRP access without oral preventive trials.

ICD10_Description: Persistent migraine aura without cerebral infarction, not intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Aura symptoms persisting ≥1 week without evidence of infarction on neuroimaging
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Rare diagnosis. Requires neuroimaging to exclude stroke.

ICD10_Description: Persistent migraine aura without cerebral infarction, not intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Aura symptoms persisting ≥1 week without evidence of infarction on neuroimaging
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Persistent aura = complex case requiring specialist management.

ICD10_Description: Persistent migraine aura without cerebral infarction, intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Persistent aura ≥1 week; failing treatment
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Complex refractory case.

ICD10_Description: Persistent migraine aura without cerebral infarction, intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Persistent aura ≥1 week; failing multiple treatments
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Supports aggressive treatment approach.

ICD10_Description: Persistent migraine aura with cerebral infarction, not intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Aura symptoms with ischemic brain lesion on neuroimaging during typical migraine with aura attack
LCD_Coverage_Notes: STROKE CODE - Triptans/ergots absolutely contraindicated. Direct CGRP access.

ICD10_Description: Persistent migraine aura with cerebral infarction, not intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Aura symptoms with documented cerebral infarction
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Stroke history = automatic triptan/ergot contraindication.

ICD10_Description: Chronic migraine without aura, not intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: ≥15 headache days/month for >3 months; ≥8 days meeting migraine criteria; history of ≥5 episodic attacks
Medications_Applicable: OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox), CGRP mAbs, Gepants, Oral preventives
LCD_Coverage_Notes: PRIMARY CODE FOR BOTOX COVERAGE. Medicare LCD L38809/DL39909 requires G43.7xx series.

ICD10_Description: Chronic migraine without aura, not intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: ≥15 headache days/month for >3 months; ≥8 days meeting migraine criteria; history of ≥5 episodic attacks
PA_Relevance: CRITICAL: Most common chronic migraine code
Medications_Applicable: OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox), CGRP mAbs, Gepants, Oral preventives
LCD_Coverage_Notes: MOST COMMONLY USED CHRONIC MIGRAINE CODE. Valid for all preventive therapies including Botox.
Common_Denial_Risks: Must document headache diary showing 15/8/4 criteria

ICD10_Description: Chronic migraine without aura, intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Chronic migraine meeting 15/8/4 criteria; failing multiple treatments
Medications_Applicable: Botox, CGRP mAbs, Dual therapy (Botox + CGRP)
LCD_Coverage_Notes: 'Intractable' supports dual therapy (Botox + CGRP mAb) per AHS 2021.

ICD10_Description: Chronic migraine without aura, intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Chronic migraine meeting 15/8/4 criteria; treatment-resistant
Medications_Applicable: Botox, CGRP mAbs, Dual therapy, Neuromodulation
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Strongest code for refractory chronic migraine. Supports aggressive treatment escalation.

ICD10_Description: Other migraine, not intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Migraine-like attacks not meeting full criteria; or episodic syndromes associated with migraine
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Less specific code. May trigger requests for additional documentation.
Common_Denial_Risks: Consider more specific code if available

ICD10_Description: Other migraine, not intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Migraine-like attacks not meeting full criteria
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Generic 'other' code. Use when specific subtype unclear.

ICD10_Description: Other migraine, intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Probable migraine failing treatment >72 hours
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Supports treatment escalation for atypical presentations.
Common_Denial_Risks: Document symptom pattern and failed treatments

ICD10_Description: Other migraine, intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Probable migraine failing multiple treatments
LCD_Coverage_Notes: 'Intractable' designation supports escalation.

ICD10_Description: Menstrual migraine, not intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Migraine occurring exclusively or predominantly on days -2 to +3 of menstruation in ≥2/3 cycles
Medications_Applicable: Triptans, Gepants, Continuous OCP, Frovatriptan prophylaxis
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Menstrual pattern supports specific prophylactic strategies.

ICD10_Description: Menstrual migraine, not intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Migraine occurring predominantly perimenstrually
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Common code for hormonally-associated migraine.

ICD10_Description: Menstrual migraine, intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Menstrual migraine >72 hours or failing treatment
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Refractory menstrual migraine may benefit from continuous CGRP suppression.

ICD10_Description: Menstrual migraine, intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Menstrual migraine failing multiple treatments
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Supports CGRP therapy for hormonally-triggered migraine.

ICD10_Description: Migraine, unspecified, not intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Migraine diagnosis without further specification
LCD_Coverage_Notes: AVOID THIS CODE WHEN POSSIBLE. Non-specific codes trigger audit flags.

ICD10_Description: Migraine, unspecified, not intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Migraine diagnosis without further specification
LCD_Coverage_Notes: COMMONLY DENIED CODE. Too vague for specialty medications.
Common_Denial_Risks: Use more specific code whenever possible

ICD10_Description: Migraine, unspecified, intractable, with status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Unspecified migraine failing treatment
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Non-specific but 'intractable' indicates severity.
Common_Denial_Risks: Document symptoms to support more specific coding

ICD10_Description: Migraine, unspecified, intractable, without status migrainosus
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Unspecified migraine failing treatment
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Better to use specific chronic/episodic code.
Common_Denial_Risks: Review records for more specific diagnosis

ICD10_Description: Drug-induced headache not elsewhere classified
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Headache ≥15 days/month developing from regular overuse of acute headache medication >3 months; simple analgesics ≥15 days; triptans/ergots/opioids/combinations ≥10 days
Medications_Applicable: CGRP mAbs, Gepants (for prevention), Detoxification protocol
LCD_Coverage_Notes: MOH diagnosis SUPPORTS gepant/CGRP access - these agents have lower MOH risk per AHS 2021.
Common_Denial_Risks: Document acute medication frequency to establish MOH

ICD10_Description: New daily persistent headache
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Daily headache from onset (<24 hours from first occurrence); clearly remembered onset date; continuous from start
Medications_Applicable: CGRP mAbs, Oral preventives, Combination therapy
LCD_Coverage_Notes: NDPH is distinct from chronic migraine. May require different treatment approach.

ICD10_Description: Headache with orthostatic component
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Headache provoked by upright posture
LCD_Coverage_Notes: NOT a migraine code. Consider CSF leak workup.
Common_Denial_Risks: Wrong code for migraine PA submissions

ICD10_Description: Headache, unspecified
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Headache without further specification
PA_Relevance: AVOID - automatic denial for specialty drugs
LCD_Coverage_Notes: DO NOT USE FOR MIGRAINE PA. Will result in automatic denial for Botox, CGRPs, gepants.
Common_Denial_Risks: Never use as primary diagnosis for migraine therapies

ICD10_Description: Cluster headache syndrome, unspecified, intractable
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Severe unilateral orbital/supraorbital/temporal pain 15-180 minutes; ipsilateral autonomic features (lacrimation, rhinorrhea, ptosis, miosis, eyelid edema, conjunctival injection); restlessness; frequency 1 every other day to 8 per day
PA_Relevance: Cluster headache prevention - Emgality 300mg only CGRP
Medications_Applicable: Galcanezumab (Emgality) 300mg, Verapamil, Lithium, SC Sumatriptan, High-flow O2
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Emgality FDA-approved for EPISODIC cluster only (G44.019). Use specific episodic/chronic code when known.
Common_Denial_Risks: Using migraine codes (G43.xxx) for cluster headache = automatic denial; chronic cluster (G44.021/029) not FDA-covered for Emgality

ICD10_Description: Cluster headache syndrome, unspecified, not intractable
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Severe unilateral orbital/supraorbital/temporal pain 15-180 minutes; ipsilateral autonomic features; restlessness; frequency 1 every other day to 8 per day
PA_Relevance: Cluster headache prevention - Emgality 300mg only CGRP
Medications_Applicable: Galcanezumab (Emgality) 300mg, Verapamil, Lithium, SC Sumatriptan, High-flow O2
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Emgality FDA-approved for EPISODIC cluster only. Use specific episodic/chronic code when known.
Common_Denial_Risks: Non-specific code; use G44.019 (episodic) for Emgality PA when possible

ICD10_Description: Episodic cluster headache, intractable
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Cluster headache attacks occurring in periods (cluster bouts) lasting 7 days to 1 year, separated by pain-free remission periods ≥3 months; ≥5 attacks meeting cluster criteria
Frequency_Threshold: Cluster periods 7 days to 1 year; remissions ≥3 months
Medications_Applicable: Galcanezumab (Emgality) 300mg - FDA APPROVED; Verapamil, Lithium, SC Sumatriptan, High-flow O2
LCD_Coverage_Notes: ⭐ PRIMARY CODE FOR EMGALITY CLUSTER HEADACHE COVERAGE. FDA approved June 2019. Use this code for Emgality PA.
Common_Denial_Risks: Must document episodic pattern (remissions ≥3 months) to distinguish from chronic cluster

ICD10_Description: Episodic cluster headache, not intractable
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Cluster headache attacks occurring in periods lasting 7 days to 1 year, separated by pain-free remission periods ≥3 months; ≥5 attacks meeting cluster criteria
Frequency_Threshold: Cluster periods 7 days to 1 year; remissions ≥3 months
Medications_Applicable: Galcanezumab (Emgality) 300mg - FDA APPROVED; Verapamil, Lithium, SC Sumatriptan, High-flow O2
LCD_Coverage_Notes: ⭐ MOST COMMON CODE FOR EMGALITY CLUSTER HEADACHE COVERAGE. FDA approved June 2019.
Common_Denial_Risks: Must clearly document episodic pattern; chronic cluster (G44.02x) NOT covered for Emgality

ICD10_Description: Chronic cluster headache, intractable
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Cluster headache attacks occurring for ≥1 year without remission, or with remission periods <3 months
Frequency_Threshold: Attacks for ≥1 year; remissions <3 months if any
PA_Relevance: ⚠️ WARNING: Emgality NOT FDA-approved for chronic cluster headache
Medications_Applicable: Verapamil, Lithium, Topiramate; Emgality OFF-LABEL ONLY (Phase 3 trial failed)
LCD_Coverage_Notes: ⛔ EMGALITY NOT FDA-APPROVED FOR CHRONIC CLUSTER. Phase 3 trial (2020) did not meet primary endpoint. EMA rejected. Off-label use only.
Common_Denial_Risks: Emgality PA will be denied for chronic cluster headache; must use episodic codes (G44.01x) for Emgality coverage

ICD10_Description: Chronic cluster headache, not intractable
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Cluster headache attacks occurring for ≥1 year without remission, or with remission periods <3 months
Frequency_Threshold: Attacks for ≥1 year; remissions <3 months if any
PA_Relevance: ⚠️ WARNING: Emgality NOT FDA-approved for chronic cluster headache
Medications_Applicable: Verapamil, Lithium, Topiramate; Emgality OFF-LABEL ONLY
LCD_Coverage_Notes: ⛔ EMGALITY NOT FDA-APPROVED FOR CHRONIC CLUSTER. Off-label use requires extensive justification.
Common_Denial_Risks: Automatic Emgality denial expected; document as refractory chronic cluster if attempting off-label appeal

ICD10_Description: Episodic paroxysmal hemicrania, intractable
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Severe unilateral pain in orbital/supraorbital/temporal region; 2-30 minutes duration; >5 attacks per day; absolute response to indomethacin
Frequency_Threshold: >5 attacks per day during cluster periods
PA_Relevance: Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia - NOT covered by Emgality indication
Medications_Applicable: Indomethacin (DIAGNOSTIC - absolute response required); NOT Emgality
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Paroxysmal hemicrania is distinct from cluster headache. Indomethacin response is diagnostic criterion.
Common_Denial_Risks: Emgality NOT indicated; indomethacin is first-line and diagnostic

ICD10_Description: Episodic paroxysmal hemicrania, not intractable
Diagnostic_Criteria_Summary: Severe unilateral pain; 2-30 minutes; >5 attacks/day; absolute indomethacin response
LCD_Coverage_Notes: Indomethacin response distinguishes PH from cluster headache.
Common_Denial_Risks: Using wrong diagnosis code; Emgality not indicated
